data.title: Hot exit should include undo history
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:16:25.899Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-78-generic

It would be great if the undo history could be saved. I especially miss that on hot exit and restart, because there you have a changed file which you can not undo (so what did I change again?).
Would be cool to have undo at least on those files.

data.title: Test: Find Widget is resizable
data.body:
Test: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5525

**Complexity**  2

- [x] **all OS**  os x @isidorn 
- [x] **all OS**   @mjbvz 
The Find Widget is now resizable. Things to note while testing

* The widget is always inside the editor
* After resizing the Find Widget, resizing the editor can still shrink/collapse/narrow down the Find Widget

data.title: Test: Find Widget no longer covers find results
data.body:
Test https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5525

**Complexity**  2

- [x] **any OS**   @roblourens 
- [x] **any OS**   @michelkaporin 

We add a viewzone before the first line when users open Find Widget, so users can scroll beyond the first line and nothing will be covered. Things to note while testing

* While viewing the middle part of the document and invoke Find Widget, the document should not shift/scroll
* The height of the viewzone is the same as Find Widget, whether Replace Input is collapsed or not.

data.title: Closes #27410 - support multi-select on open file/changes commands

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27410

Also stops the opening of an editor from stealing focus -- so that it is much easier to keyboard around (it also aligns with the behavior of the main file explorer)

That there are comments in the code noting things that need to be changed once PR https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/27357 is merged.

data.title: Git: Allow Open File & Open Changes commands to support multi-select

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (770206ab9c6357943a2145bd3ea49b667f3ff539, 2017-05-26T05:14:23.944Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
---

Currently you can multi-select items in the Git files view and if you right-click, the `Open File` & `Open Changes` menu items will only open the file/change of the focused item, with the stage/unstage command work with the whole selection. It would be great to have these 2 command act upon the whole selection.

data.title: Fixes #27408 - stops forcing column ONE as the default
data.body:
See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27408

This allows `showTextDocument` & `vscode.diff` to be defaulted to the active column.

data.title: showTextDocument & vscode.diff always default to ViewColumn.One
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (770206ab9c6357943a2145bd3ea49b667f3ff539, 2017-05-26T05:14:23.944Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
---

These 2 apis should honor the ViewColumn if specified, but if left `undefined` they should default to the column of the active editor

Having this will eliminate code in many extensions such as:
```ts
(window.activeTextEditor && window.activeTextEditor.viewColumn) || 1
```

Which fails for anything that isn't a text document (since `viewColumn` will be missing)

data.title: Handle diff3-style merge correctly
data.body:
Fixes pprice/vscode-better-merge#23.

I'm using `merge.conflictStyle = diff3` git setting, but the style (_Current/Common ancestors/Incoming_) is not supported in VS Code. In the new merge extension (#27150), the _Common ancestors_ block is merged together with the _Current_ block. This PR adds that support. As `diff3` is a superset of the default git conflict style, I've modified the original algorithm to support both styles. The same fix was also proposed by @spiffytech in the original issue.

data.title: Need an opinion on possible solutions when dealing with files not informing their content type in C++

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2
- OS Version: Debian Jessie
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.2|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

Working on C++ projects, new entries are generated in `files.associations` just because I navigated to a file that do not inform vscode about its content type (no extension, etc.). But, `settings.json` is a file meant to be tracked by the VCS. I am currently being forced to `.gitignore` this file to not be bothered by new entries appearing regularly.

Example of file: `iostream`

---

Of course, I asked about this situation on vscode-cpptools first (Microsoft/vscode-cpptools#722) where I got the following answer:

"Our tool automatically adds a c/cpp to file.associations whenever the a C/C++ file with an extensionless or non-standard file extension is navigated to via a source file -- this enables the header file to be treated as C/C++ for colorization and other features (otherwise, it opens as a text file). The only mechanism VS Code provides for enabling this scenario is updating the files.associations setting, which is stored in the settings.json, and there's no mechanism for storing other settings elsewhere. If you have a proposed alternative design, it would probably have to be implemented in VS Code itself (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues ). One potential solution is for the openTextDocument called internally by VS on a Go To Definition to automatically supply the languageID of the source file. We could also add a setting to turn off this behavior or you could modify the /out/src/C_Cpp.js yourself to replace code con.update("associations", assoc); with ; (and/or add a script to do the replacement for when the file is overwritten by an update)." @sean-mcmanus Microsoft/vscode-cpptools#722

Thank you @sean-mcmanus

---

It feels like a solution to this problem could involve a vscode enhancement / feature. We would be pleased to have your opinion on that. :)

data.title: Settings search -- can't easily search your own settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (770206ab9c6357943a2145bd3ea49b667f3ff539, 2017-05-26T05:14:23.944Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
---

Before the unified search/filter bar at the top of the settings, you used to be able to open the find widget and easily search your own settings. This is no longer possible and imo sorely missed. While the unified search does show the matches, it doesn't jump to them, there is no way to navigate to the next occurrence, and they don't even show on the scrollbar. Ideally, imo, the find widget should still be accessible for the right side (user/workspace) settings

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open settings `ctrl+,`
2. Try searching you own settings -- observe the issues outlined above

data.title: find.history.showPrevious/Next and search.history.showPrevious/Next should be available in the command palette
data.body: The commands in the title are not discoverable through the command palette, you have to open the keybindings.json.

data.title: Incremental search causes text overwrite in code editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use an extension that refreshes previewHTML content on selection change and open a file that activates this extension (the markdown extension is not a good example for this problem, as it doesn't refresh content, just scrolls).
2. Open a window with the previewHTML content.
3. Start an incremental search and type letters which move the selection around and see your previewHTML getting updated.
4. As soon as this happens the focus is moved to the editor window (instead of staying in the search field), which causes the next keypress to overwrite text in the editor, instead of continue searching.

data.title: Separate the task provider name from the task name in the task API
data.body:
Today a task provider prefixes a task with the name of the task provider.  For example, the `gulp` task provider:
```typescript
new vscode.ShellTask(`gulp: ${line}`, `${gulpCommand} ${line}`);
```
All tasks repeat the `gulp:` prefix. We should separate the task provider name from the task in the API (same as we do it for the source of diagnostics). This will allow for example, to show tasks in a tree without the task provider prefix.
```
gulp 
  build
  test
npm
  install
```

data.title: Test snippet changes
data.body:
#Test for: #24855, #16037, and #5427
Complexity: 3

- [x] Any OS - @dbaeumer 
- [x] Any OS - @mjbvz 

The snippet controller has been re-implemented to fix bugs and to unlock some feature, mostly real multi-cursor support. Refresh your snippet skills here: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/userdefinedsnippets#_snippet-syntax. Test that

* you can navigate between snippet placeholders with tab and shift+tab
* when reaching the last final placeholder snippet mode ends
* pressing ESC exists snippet mode and leaves the cursor where it is
* snippet mode stays active when the editor loses focus
* snippet mode exists as soon as a cursor moves out of its snippet placeholder
* a snippet with placeholders can be inserted when multiple cursors are in use
* snippet variables that refer to the line context (number, offset, selection etc) work in the context of their line, esp. when multiple cursors are at work
* a snippet placeholder can be filled in with another snippet and their placeholders can be navigated as if you have only one snippet

data.title: UX: align file names when renaming
data.body: When renaming a file or a folder in the explorer sidebar, you can see that its name has an offset of 1px because of the border of the input box. Although that's trivial, it is something interrupting for me. May we make the input box move left 1px so that the names will be aligned?

data.title: Wrong bulb actions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (7403245d3d42edab8d0c728cf56b8a2db097db7f, 2017-05-23T05:14:19.493Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
- Extensions: the listing exceeds the lower minimum of browsers' URL characters limit
---

I have imported `waitMessages` function
```ts
import { createConfirmationMessage, waitForMessages } from "../utils/interactive";
```

Then I typing somewhere in code something like
```ts
await waitForMessages(__msg.channel as DMChannel)
```

But I don't have imported DMChannel from external lib, linter warns me about it:
```
[ts] Cannot find name 'DMChannel'.
```

I pressing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>.</kbd> to import `DMChannel` faster, but I'm finding, that VSCode thinks I need to import `waitForMessages` function (which is already imported)

![2017-05-28_15-21-07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10401817/26527245/101ca894-43ba-11e7-9ba3-4b9d6230d059.gif)

data.title: SERIOUS BUG: Node debug sometimes shows incorrect working directory
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try running a node app with configuration like this:
```
       {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/server.js"
        }
```

2. Sometimes, process.cwd() will show this:
```
/Users/Me/nodeapp
```
**^ THIS ONE IS CORRECT.**

And sometimes it will show this:
```
/Users/Me/nodeapp/bin
```
**^ THIS ONE IS INCORRECT.**

data.title: Rename symbol occasionally stalls forever (and language services seem to stop entirely)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.7.0|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.2.0|
|vscode-new-file|dkundel|3.0.2|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.7.0|
|vscode-open-in-github|sysoev|1.5.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone github.com/ouranos-oss/js-image and open in VSCode
2. Open a typescript file for editing
3. Attempt to rename an exported function symbol
4. Watch the blue loading bar go across the top of the screen forever, closing the file and reopening makes the loading go away but subsequent renames in any file will fail until vscode is closed. Additionally, doing anything to break compilation here will not yield the red underlines, etc

This doesn't happen every time unfortunately I wish I had a minimized repro scenario for you :/ Restarting fixes the problem, but after a couple of hours of work the issue returns I usually have to restart at least once a day. I don't see any errors in "Output", "Problems" (which is empty even with compilation errors present), "Debug Console", or inspecting with DevTools when this happens. 

Any additional info on how to gather more helpful info next time this happens would be great!

data.title: Add option to use windows keymap on MacOS

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 

We can write `keybindings` in `package.json` (Extension Manifest File).
```json
"keybindings": [
    {
        "win": "ctrl+y",
        "mac": "cmd+backspace",
        "linux": "ctrl+y",
        "command": "editor.action.deleteLines",
        "when": "editorTextFocus && !editorReadonly"
    }
]
```
I got a request from some developers that they are using macOS but they want to use Windows keybindings. See [Add option to use windows keymap on MacOS](https://github.com/k--kato/vscode-intellij-idea-keybindings/issues/67).

So, I'd like to switch `mac` and `win` in `settings.json` or something. Can I do this?
